results.title: Theremin: An Electronic Odyssey documentary poster
results.brief_description: Poster for the documentary ‘Theremin: An Electronic Odyssey.’ This documentary explores the life of Leon Theremin, the inventor of an electronic synthesizer called the theremin, which uses motion to produce a sliding ethereal sound. After creating the instrument, Theremin is kidnapped by the KGB to work on inventions and surveillance technology. During his absence, the theremin becomes a popular instrument in film scores and through the performances of Clara Rockmore. In 1991, Theremin finally returns to the United States after his release.

results.title: 400 Porto-Arc 16mm projector
results.brief_description: Carbon arc projectors were common until WWII, and it’s rare to see one as late as the 1950s. Because of the intensity of the light in these projectors, they were mostly used in large auditoriums, despite being designed as a lightweight travelling projector.

constellations_primary.name: Movies in movies in a movie museum
constellations_primary.description: The 400 Porto-Arc 16mm projector used the first electric light ever invented, which was perfectly suited for movie projectors. This Constellation explores the movies where characters go to the movies, by two movie-obsessed directors.

results.description:
Carbon arc projectors use the first electric light ever invented. Arc lamps were commonly found in streetlamps during the 1870s, gradually replaced by incandescent light in the early 20th century. But in situations that called for a high-intensity light, like movie projectors, arc lamps still had a role.

Carbon arc projectors were common until WWII, and it’s rare to see one as late as the 1950s. Because of the intensity of the light in these projectors, they were mostly used in large auditoriums, despite being designed as a lightweight travelling projector. They were marketed as the best bet for screening 16mm film in tents, at road shows, at fairs in rural areas and outdoors – as long as there was a power source!
description_for_label:
Carbon arc projectors use the first electric light ever invented. Arc lamps were commonly found in streetlamps during the 1870s, gradually replaced by incandescent light in the early 20th century. But in situations that called for a high-intensity light, like movie projectors, arc lamps still had a role.

Carbon arc projectors were common until WWII, and it’s rare to see one as late as the 1950s. Because of the intensity of the light in these projectors, they were mostly used in large auditoriums, despite being designed as a lightweight travelling projector. They were marketed as the best bet for screening 16mm film in tents, at road shows, at fairs in rural areas and outdoors – as long as there was a power source!

results.title: Like drowning
results.creator_credit: Catherine Murphy, Ann Shenfield, Paul Fletcher, Robert Stephenson and Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television
results.brief_description: A moving animated tale about a young family who try to come to terms with the sudden death of one of the children through drowning. The family struggles to cope and adopt drastic changes in their lifestyle in order to come to terms with the ordeal.

results.title: Clapperboard (studio of Mirka Mora)
results.brief_description: Clapperboard made from wood and painted black and white, board has cloth tape around middle and bottom sections. Back of board has a piece of paper attached with rows of numbers.

results.title: Did you ask the river?
results.credit_line:
Joan Ross
Mordant Family VR Commission, ACMI Collection
Developed in collaboration with Dr Josh Harle at Tactical Space Lab, Sydney
results.material_description: software, video, props, colour and sound
results.brief_description:
‘Did you ask the river?’ is the debut VR work from one of Australia’s leading visual artists, Joan Ross.

In the style of a first-person videogame, participants are given free rein to explore an interactive 3D extension of Ross’s vibrant, yet unsettling, colonial landscapes.

Unlike many VR experiences, participants are placed in a body – that of an 18th century colonial woman – and become uncomfortably complicit in her unwitting destruction of the landscape.

results.title: Motion pictures. 1st 20 years. Part 1: 1898-1903
results.brief_description:
A compilation of silent films from 1898-1903. Films restored from the Library of Congress paper prints.
Contents: Elopement on horseback (1898)—Strange adventure of N.Y. Drummer (1899)—Uncle Josh’s nightmare (1900)—Terrible Teddy, the grizzly king (1901)—Love by the light of the moon (1901)—Panarama of esplanade by night (1901)—Martyred presidents (1901)—Uncle Josh at the moving picture show (1902)—Fun in a bakery shop (1902)—Jack and the beanstalk (1902)— Life of an American fireman (1903)
